title: I have received a request for Entry of Default Clerks Judgment from a collection agency. I don't believe I have been served.
question: As I have never signed anything or been approached to sign anything.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Sued for debt,Default judgment
answers: You have a default judgment against you if you have been served with that document. You need to file a motion to vacate the judgment.

Check the County Superior Court's website to find out or call the clerk of the court with the case number. Default judgments without valid service occur many times every day. People believe that they need to sign something, but that is not correct. A process server goes to serve the defendant and can hand it to the defend and walk away or, if several attempts at service at the home or workplace have failed, they can give it to the adult at the premises and then regular mail a copy, which is known as substitute service. I have a blog, linked below, on service and also on options when a default judgment is entered.

One of the options is to promptly set aside the default judgment by motion or by stipulation. If not done promptly upon learning of the lawsuit and default judgment, a judge many deny the motion. You may need to consult and hire a debt collection DEFENSE lawyer to help you at this point, because if the motion to set aside a default is denied, you may be stuck with resolving at a very high price the default judgment, as explained in my options blog.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
www.facebook.com/SoCalConsumerLawyer
Twitter: @RStempler

You do not need to sign anything to have been served. If you received a Request to Enter Default and/or Request to Enter Clerk's Judgment, you need to immediately move to set aside your default and any resulting judgment. Hopefully, there is enough time. Generally, the outside limit is 6 months from entry of default. If your default is set aside, i.e., if you file the motion and it is granted, you will then be given an opportunity to defend the lawsuit. Good luck. -- Michael
